Pae. 5.36:—in Med., found, μυρία δʼ ἄστη νάσσατʼ ἐποιχόμενος A.R. 4.275:—in Pass., of places, like Act. I.2, to be situated, πολίων εὖ ναιομενάων Il. 3.400, al.
let one dwell, settle him, ἐν Ἄργει ἔνασσεν Ἡρακλέος ἐκγόνους Pi. P. 5.71:— in Med., νάσσατο κούρην A.R. 4.567.

definition: ναός, ὁ, Dor., Thess., etc. form, Leg.Gort. 1.42, IG 9(2).517.45 ( Larissa, iii B.C.), etc., used also in Trag. (even dialogue) to the exclusion of νεώς, S. El. 8, E. Hipp. 31, al., exc. A. Pers. 810, rare in Att. Prose and Com., Pl. R. 394a, Lg. 738c, 814b, Arist. EN 1174a24, Posidipp. 29.1, more freq. in X., HG 2.3.20, An. 5.3.9, al., found in Att. Inscrr.from iii B.C., IG 2(2).1314.18, 1315.28, etc., and in Hellenistic and later Gr. (along with νεώς), SIG 277 ( Priene, iv B.C.), 214 ( Phanagoria, iv B.C.), 494.3 ( Delph., iii B.C.), LXX 1 Ki. 1.9, al. ( νεώς only in 2 Ma.), UPZ 6.22 (ii B.C.), Plb. 9.30.2 ( νεώς Plb. 10.4.4), etc.; Ion. νηός, always in Hom. and Hdt. (v. infr.), but gen. νε[ώ] IG 12(7).1.4 ( Amorgos, v B.C.); dat. νειῴ Michel 832.38 ( Samos, iv B.C.); Att. νεώς (Attic Inscrr. of v- iii B.C. (v. infr.), once in Trag. (v. supr.), freq. in Prose authors and found in Com. (v. infr.)); declension, nom. νεώς X. HG 1.6.1; gen. νεώ IG 1(2).4.9, 80.6, Ar. Pl. 733, IG 2(2).1524.45, SIG 1219.32 ( Gambreum, iii B.C.); dat. νεῴ IG 1(2).6.122, 256.4, Antipho 6.39, Alex. 40.3, IG 2(2).1504.7; acc. νεών ib. 12.24.13, al., X. HG 6.5.9, Ar. Nu. 401, Pl. 741, Philem. 139, f.l. in E. HF 340, later νεώ IG 2(2).212.35 (iv B.C.), al., LXX 2 Ma. 6.2, al., D.S. 16.58 (v.l. νεών), SIG 877 A 10 (ii/ iii A.D.), v.l. in D.H. 4.26, but νεών Aristid. Or. 27(16).19 (v.l. νεώ), Ach.Tat. 3.6 (v.l. νεώ Bast Epist.Crit. p.176), etc.: pl. nom. νεῴ X. HG 6.4.7; acc. νεώς A. Pers. 810, Isoc. 5.117, Plb. 10.4.4; dat. νεῴς IG 1(2).384; on the accent v. Hdn.Gr. 1.8: Aeol. ναῦος Alc. 9, IG 12 (2).60.27 (Mytil.); Spartan ναϝός ib. 5(1).1564 (pl., found at Delos, v/iv B.C.):—

definition: ναρεῖ τηρεῖ, Hsch. (cf. ναρούς). νάρειν· κύειν, κρύπτειν, ζητεῖν, κυΐσκεσθαι, ἀμέλγεσθαι, Id. νάρη· ἡ ἄφρων καὶ μωρά, Id.
ναρθηκία, ἡ, a plant allied to νάρθηξ, Thphr. HP 6.1.4, 6.2.7.

children.definition: beat with a νάρθηξ or rod, Hsch.
splint a broken limb (orig. with pieces of νάρθηξ), τὸ σφυρόν Sch. Ar. Ach. 1176, cf. Heraclas ap. Orib. 48.2.2, Paul.Aeg. 6.106.
splint planks together with laths, in Pass., Apollod. Poliorc. 159.4.
made of νάρθηξ, Arist. Aud. 803a41.
small splint, Antyll. ap. Orib. 44.23.74.
small rod used in ἐπίκρουσις I, Gal. 10.998.
splint, Apollod. Poliorc. 159.13.
Dsc. Eup. 1.233.
splinting of planks with laths, Apollod. Poliorc. 160.6.
like the νάρθηξ, Dsc. 3.81.
filling the hollow of the νάρθηξ, πυρὸς πηγή A. Pr. 109.
looking like νάρθηξ, Archig. ap. Orib. 8.2.3.

carrying a wand of νάρθηξ, like the Βάκχαι (cf. θυρσοφόρος), Plu. Col. 2.1107f; of Dionysus, Orph. H. 42.1; prov., πολλοί τοι ν., παῦροι δέ τε Βάκχοι, i.e. there are many officials, but few inspired, Zen. 5.77, cf. Pl. Phd. 69c, Orph. Fr. 5.
rod-bearer, X. Cyr. 2.3.18.
like a νάρθηξ, Thphr. HP 1.6.10, Gp. 5.8.2.

giant fennel, Ferula communis, Thphr. HP 1.2.7, Dsc. 3.77, etc.; κλέψας . . πυρὸς τηλέσκοπον αὐγὴν ἐν κοίλῳ ν., of Prometheus, Hes. Th. 567, cf. Op. 52; of the stalk used as a θύρσος, E. Ba. 147 (lyr.), al.; as a schoolmasterʼs cane, X. Cyr. 2.3.20, cf. Arist. Pr. 948a10; as a splint for a broken limb, Hp. Off. 12, Gal. 10.437; single-stick for military exercises, Onos. 10.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: casket for unguents, etc., Luc. Ind. 29; ἡ ἐκ τοῦ ν. διόρθωσις, of Aristotleʼs recension of Homer, carried by Alexander in a ν., Str. 13.1.27, Plu. Alex. 8.

children.label: III
children.definition: fore-court of a church, EM 597.48.

a fragrant Indian bark, used as a spice, etc. (perh. the same as λάκαφθον), Dsc. 1.23:—written ναόκαφθον and νάκαφθον in most codd. of Paul.Aeg. 7.3; νάκαφθον in one cod. of Id. 7.22.4 (v.l. λάκαφθον).

grow stiff or numb, χεὶρ νάρκησε Il. 8.328; τὴν ψυχὴν καὶ τὸ στόμα ναρκῶ Pl. Men. 80b; ψυχῆς ναρκώσης Democr. 290; τὸ ἡσυχάζον ναρκᾷ Epicur. Sent.Vat. 11; τὸ νεῦρον ὃ ἐνάρκησεν LXX Ge. 32.32(33); χεὶρ νεναρκηκυῖα J. AJ 8.8.5; of the numbness caused by the fish νάρκη, Arist. HA 620b19, cf. Pl. Men. 84b; ναρκῶ, ναὶ τὸν Πᾶνα Theoc. 27.51.

data.quote: τὴν ψυχὴν καὶ τὸ στόμα ναρκῶ

children.definition: numbness, deadness, caused by palsy, frost, fright, etc., Hp. VM 22, Aph. 5.25; ν. κατὰ τῆς χειρὸς καταχεῖται Ar. V. 713, cf. Arist. HA 515b20, Pr. 867b29, 954a23 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: torpedo, electric ray, which benumbs any one who touches it, Antiph. 132.2, Anaxandr. 41.52, etc.; ἡ πλατεῖα ν. ἡ θαλαττία Pl. Men. 80a, cf. Arist. HA 620b19; ν. ποταμία the Egyptian electric eel, Malapterurus electricus, PMag.Osl. 1.284, cf. Ath. 7.312b: in metapl. acc. νάρκᾰ Opp. C. 3.55.
torpor, Gloss.
made of narcissus, Cratin. 344, Dsc. 1.53.

children.label: II
children.definition: of the colour of νάρκισσος, PRyl. 154.8 (i A.D.).
like the narcissus, [ λίθος] D.P. 1031, Plin. HN 37.188.

narcissus, of various species, h.Cer. 8, 428, S. OC 683 (lyr.), Mosch. 2.65; pheasantʼs eye, Narcissus poeticus, Thphr. HP 6.8.1, Dsc. 4.158; autumn narcissus, N. serotinus, Thphr. HP 6.6.9; Narcissus Tazetta, polyanthus narcissus, Dsc. l.c. (this prob. in S. l.c.). (Connected with νάρκη, because of its narcotic properties, acc. to Plu. QConv. 2.647b.)
benumb, deaden, ὀδύνην ναρκοῖ Hp. Liqu. 6; νεναρκωμένοι ib. 1: c. acc. pers., Phld. Rh. 1.380 S., cf. Hp. Epid. 6.2.1.

numb, torpid, Hp. Art. 48 ( Comp.), Dsc. 3.101; τὸ ν. νεῦρον, in the elbow, Hp. Mochl. 1, cf. Prorrh. 1.139, Art. 19; βαρύτητες ν. Plu. QConv. 2.647b; πόνος ν. Gal. 8.70; sluggish, ὁρμαί Phld. D. 1.13. Ion. Adv. ναρκωδέως Hp. Prorrh. 1.120, Mul. 2.145.
a benumbing, γνώμης Hp. Aph. 5.16.
benumbing, narcotic, φάρμακα Gal. 10.862, al., Eust. 1493.5.
flowing, liquid, Δίρκη A. Fr. 347; ναρὰ καὶ κρηναῖα ποτά S. Fr. 621; cf. νηρός.

definition: ναρούς τοὺς φύλακας, Hsch. (Perh. Dor. contr. from νᾱορ ( ϝ)-, cf. ναρεῖ, ναυρός.)
νάρτη, ἡ, plant used in perfumery, Thphr. HP 9.7.3.

children.definition: Hsch. νᾶς, ἡ, Dor. for ναῦς. νάσθη, v. ναίω. νᾱσιώτας, α, ὁ, Aeol. and Dor. for νησιώτης. νάσκαφθον, τό, v. νάρκαφθον.
flowing: stream, spring, E. Hipp. 225 (anap.), 653; φοινισσομένην αἵματι . . , νασμῷ μελαναυγεῖ Id. Hec. 153 (anap.); εὐδρόσοισι Κασταλίας ν. Aristonous 1.43.
Hsch. νάσσα, νάσσατο, v. ναίω. νᾶσσα, Boeot. for νῆσσα, νῆττα.

definition: νάσσω, Att. νάττω, fut. νάξω Hsch.: aor. ἔναξα (v. infr.): pf. Pass. νένασμαι and νέναγμαι (v. infr.):—

children.definition: press, squeeze close, stamp down, γαῖαν ἔναξε Od. 21.122; οἱ παῖδες ἔναττον εἰς τὰς σπυρίδας Hippoloch. ap. Ath. 4.130b:— Pass., to be piled up, ἡ κόπρος ἡ νεναγμένη Hp. Nat.Puer. 24; ἐν δὲ [τῇ στιβάδι] νένασται . . δέρματα Theoc. 9.9: c. gen., κλῖναι σισυρῶν νεναγμέναι ( νενασμ- codd.) piled up with . . , Ar. Ec. 840.

children.label: II
children.definition: stuff quite full, νάττω τὸν θύλακον Epict. Fr. 23:— Pass., πᾶσα οἰκία ὁπλιτῶν νένακτο was crammed with . . , J. BJ 1.17.6.
inhabitant, Zonar.
Dim. of ναστός I.3, Pherecr. 130.7.
cutting up cakes, Pl.Com. 246.
close-pressed, firm, Hp. Gland. 16; κάλαμος, i.e. archerʼs reed, Arundo Plinii, Dsc. 1.85; of a tumour, Aët. 15.8; σφυγμός Archig. ap. Gal. 8.931: Comp., Id.ib. 509.
solid, opp. κενός, Democr. ap. Arist. Fr. 208, cf. Ph. 1.330, Simp. in Cael. 295.5.
ναστός (sc. πλακοῦς), ὁ, well-kneaded cake, esp. used in sacrifice, cheese-cake, Pherecr. 108.5, Ar. Av. 567, Pl. 1142, Metag. 6.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: filled full of, πόλις ναστὴ ἀνδρῶν J. BJ 6.9.4.
solidity, absence of void, Alex.Aphr. in Metaph. 35.27, Simp. in Cael. 609.18, in de An. 64.3, Phlp. in Ph. 506.6.
eat cakes, Poll. 6.75, Hsch.
eating cakes, Poll. 6.75.

definition: νατῆρες ὑπηρέται, ἢ κεραμίδες, Hsch. νατταρέον· πολύρρουν, Id. (leg. νᾶτορ· ῥέων, πολύρρους).

children.definition: flowing, Ἴναχε, νᾶτορ παῖ . . Ὠκεανοῦ S. Fr. 270 (anap.), cf. foreg. and ναέτωρ.

definition: ναυαγέω, Ion. ναυηγ-, pf. νεναυάγηκα Hdt. 7.236 (- ηγ-), Eub. 76: ( ναῦς, ἄγνυμι):—

children.definition: suffer shipwreck, Hdt. l.c., X. Cyr. 3.1.24, D. 34.10, etc.: metaph., of chariots, Id. 61.29; of an earthen vessel, A. Fr. 180; of persons, ν. ἐν τοῖς ἰδίοις Thphr. ap. D.L. 5.55, cf. Phld. Vit. p.33 J.; ἐν τῷ βίῳ Ceb. 24.2; περὶ τὴν πίστιν 1 Ep.Ti. 1.19; χὡ μὲν ἐναυάγει γαίης ἔπι AP 5.208 ( Posidipp. or Asclep.); ναυαγεῖ συμπόσια μὴ τυχόντα παιδαγωγίας ὀρθῆς Plu. QConv. 2.622b.

data.quote: ναυαγεῖ συμπόσια μὴ τυχόντα παιδαγωγίας ὀρθῆς

children.definition: shipwreck, Hdt. 7.190, 192, al., E. Hel. 1070, etc.; ναυαγίᾳ χρῆσθαι, περιπίπτειν, Luc. VH 2.35, Tox. 2: in pl., Pi. I. 1.36 (s. v. l.); ἐν χειμῶνι καὶ ναυαγίαις Ar. Th. 873.

piece of wreckage, Men. 536.9, Arist. Pr. 932a1: mostly in pl., A. Pers. 420, Hdt. 7.191, 8.12, al., Lys. 2.38, Th. 1.50, etc.; πολλοὺς ἀριθμοὺς ἄγνυται ναυαγίων, i. e. is shivered into a thousand pieces, E. Hel. 410: metaph., ν. ἱππικά wreck of an overturned chariot, S. El. 730, 1444; ἀνδρῶν δαιτυμόνων ν. the wreck of a feast, Choeril. 9; τὰ ν. τῆς πόλεως Demad. ap. Plu. Praec. 2.803a; ν. οἴκων Curios. ib. 517f.

definition: ναυαγός, όν, Ion. ναυηγός (also in late Prose, Alciphr. 1.18),

children.definition: shipwrecked, Hdt. 4.103, E. Hel. 408, Philem. 213.3; ναυαγοὺς ἀναιρεῖσθαι pick up shipwrecked men, X. HG 1.7.4; ν. τάφος, i. e. a watery grave, AP 7.76 ( Diosc.); ν. μόρος ib. 9.84 ( Antiphan.).
Act., causing shipwreck, ἄνεμοι ib. 105.

command a fleet, Hdt. 7.161, X. An. 5.1.4, IG 12(8).183 ( Samothrace), Phld. Rh. 2.209 S.: c. gen., ν. [πλοίων] Philipp. ap. D. 18.77.

Lyd. Mag. 1.27.
command of a fleet, Th. 8.20, 33; period of such command, X. HG 1.5.1: pl., Arist. Pol. 1322b3.

admiralʼs flagship, Plb. 1.51.1, D.S. 11.27, Plu. Alc. 27, Longus 2.28; ν. τριήρης D.S. 20.7.

Aj. 1232; esp. the Spartan admiral-in-chief, Th. 4.11, 8.6, 20, 23, X. An. 1.4.2, etc.; used of an inferior naval officer, Decr. ap. D. 18.73; nauarchorum coetus circiter provincias Orientis, Cod.Just. 11.2.4.

weigh down a ship, Ph. 2.465.

seafarer, seaman, Hdt. 1.143, A. Pers. 1011 (lyr.), S. Ph. 301, 540, Th. 1.121, Rev.Bibl. 14.290 ( Megiste), etc.

cubic measure in Egypt, with side = two royal cubits (in Roman times, three cubits), used with application to earth as a unit of labour, in pl., PLille 1r. 11, Wilcken Chr. 385.8, PPetr. 3pp. 80,290, Ostr.Bodl. i 244 (all iii B. C.), Arch.Pap. 6.132 (i A. D.), POxy. 669.11 (iii A. D.):—written ναούια ib. 1053 (vi/vii A. D.).
ναύβια, PTeb. 5.15 (ii B. C.); ν. κατοίκων, ἐναφεσίων, BGU 662 (ii A. D.), PTeb. 352 (ii A. D.).
Ostr. 1396 (i A. D.), Ostr.Bodl. iii 84 (i A. D.).

definition: Ναυδαμηνός, ὁ, epith. of Zeus at Sinope, AJP 9.303.

children.definition: shipʼs cable, E. Tr. 811 (lyr.).

definition: ναυηγέω, ναυ-ηγία, ναυ-ήγιον, ναυ-ηγός, Ion. for ναυαγ-.

children.definition: Hsch.
to be a shipowner, Ar. Av. 598, X. Lac. 7.1, Lys. 6.49; Ἐρασικλῆς μαρτυρεῖ κυβερνᾶν τὴν ναῦν ἣν Ὑβλήσιος ἐναυκλήρει Test. ap. D. 35.20: c. gen., φορτηγὸν ἧς ἐναυκλήρει Ῥωμαῖος ἀνήρ Plu. Pomp. 73.
ν. πόλιν manage, govern, A. Th. 652, S. Ant. 994.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be manager of a tenement-house (v. ναύκληρος II), ν. συνοικίαν ἐν Πειραιεῖ Is. 6.19, cf. Alex. 138.
voyage, Tz. H. 9.60 (pl.).
life and calling of a ναύκληρος, ship-owning, Lys. 6.19, Pl. Lg. 643e, Arist. Pol. 1258b22, etc.: in pl., And. 1.137, Vett.Val. 73.6.
voyage, S. Fr. 143, E. Alc. 112 (lyr.).
adventure, enterprise, Id. Med. 527.

children.label: II
children.definition: ship, Id. Hel. 1519, Plu. Util. 2.87a.
of or for a ναύκληρος, Luc. DMeretr. 2.2; ν. δίαιτα Moschio ap. Ath. 5.207c; ν. ἄνθρωποι Peripl.M.Rubr. 21; τὰ -κά, = ναυκληρία, Pl. Lg. 842d.
ship of a ναύκληρος, in pl., property in ships, D. 23.211, Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.234f: sg., POxy. 87.7 (iv A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: E. Rh. 233 (lyr., pl.).
pilot of a ναυκλήριον, Wilcken Chr. 434.4 (iv A. D.), etc.
sailor in the fleet of the Ptolemies, PTeb. 5.46 (ii B. C.), UPZ 110.22 (ii B. C.).
shipowner and merchant (opp. ἔμπορος, q. v.), IG 1(2).127.34, 128.4, Hdt. 1.5, 4.152, S. Ph. 128, 547, E. Fr. 417, Ar. Av. 595, Th. 1.137, X. Mem. 3.9.11.
skipper, sailing-master, OGI 344.4 ( Delos, ii B. C.), Act.Ap. 27.11, POxy. 63.4 (ii/iii A. D.).
captain, commander, A. Supp. 177: as Adj., ν. πλάτη S. Fr. 430; ν. χείρ the masterʼs hand, of a charioteer, E. Hipp. 1224; ν. πόλις Philostr. VS 2.26.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: one who rented and sub-let tenement-houses, Sannyr. 6, Hyp. Fr. 37, Diph. 37, cf. Hsch., Poll. 1.75.
Id. 8.108 (s. v. l.); cf. ναύκλαρος.
to be sub-let to lodgers, στέγαι Hsch.
registry of the ναύκραροι, Ammon. Diff. p.94 V.; ναυκραρεῖα in Thom.Mag. p.246R.
naucrary (v. ναύκραρος), Arist. Ath. 8.3, Clidem. 8, Phot.
of or for a ναύκραρος or ναυκραρία, ἀργύριον Lex Solonis ap. Arist. Ath. 8.3, cf. Harp. s.v. ναυκραρικά.

the chief official of a division ( ναυκραρία) of the citizens for financial and administrative purposes, Lex Solonis ap. Arist. Ath. 8.3, etc.; οἱ πρυτάνιες τῶν ν. Hdt. 5.71; [ Κλεισθένης] κατέστησε δημάρχους τὴν αὐτὴν ἔχοντας ἐπιμέλειαν τοῖς πρότερον ν. Arist. Ath. 21.5; cf. ναύκληρος II.2, ναύκλαρος. ( -κραρος prob. = ‘chief’, cf. pr. n. [ Λ]ακραρίδας IG 7.1931: from - κρᾱσρος, cf. κάρα.)

data.quote: Κλεισθένης] κατέστησε δημάρχους τὴν αὐτὴν ἔχοντας ἐπιμέλειαν τοῖς πρότερον ν.

children.definition: have the command of the sea, Th. 7.60:— Pass., to be mastered at sea, X. HG 6.2.8.
master or mistress of the sea, ναυκρατέες τῆς θαλάσσης Hdt. 5.36.
holding a ship fast: name of a fish, τὴν ἐχενηΐδα ναυκράτην ἔγραψέ τις Eust. 1490.19, cf. Cyran. 31.
of or for victory at sea, σημεῖον D.C. 51.21.
naval victory, And. Fr. 3, D.C. 49.7, etc.
Naucratis in Egypt, Hdt. 2.97; Ναυκρατίτης [ ῑ], ου, ὁ, a Naucratite, Call. Epigr. 40, Str. 17.1.33; στέφανος N., = σάμψυχος, Anacr. 83:— Adj. Ναυκρατῑτικός, ή, όν, D. 24.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: master of a ship, S. Ph. 1072.

definition: ναῦλα, ἡ, later form for νάβλα, Aq. Ps. 32(33).2, Sm. Ps. 91(92).4.

children.definition: Sammelb. 4425iv32 (ii A. D.).
1a, IG 11 (2).165.55, al. ( Delos, iii B. C.), Sch. Ar. Ra. 272:—also ναῦλλος, ὁ, Sch. Ar. l.c.; acc. ναῦλλον (gender indeterminate) IG 2(2).1128.13.
receiver of freights, Ostr. 1477 (ii A. D.).
νάβλα, Hsch. s.v. νάβλας.

children.label: II
children.definition: v. sq.

definition: ναῦλος, ὁ, Ar. (v. infr.), IG 2(2).1672.126,159, SIG 1262.6 ( Smyrna, i A. D.), Com.Adesp. 286; also ἡ, acc. to Sch. Ar. Ra. 272; and ναῦλον, τό (v. infr.), cf. ναῦλλον:—

children.definition: passage-money, fare or freight, ἔκβαινʼ, ἀπόδος τὸν ν., says Charon, Ar. Ra. 270; τῆς πόλεως ναῦλον τελούσης τοῖς ἄγουσι τοὺς λίθους IPE 12.32B50 ( Olbia, iii B. C.); ναῦλον συνθέσθαι to agree upon oneʼs fare, X. An. 5.1.12; τὸ ν. τῶν ξύλων παρασχεῖν D. 49.26, cf. IG ll. cc.; τὸ ν. ἀποστερεῖν Din. 1.56; παραπόλλυμι τὸ ν. Arisipp. ap. Plu. Virt. doc. 2.439e; ἔδωκε τὸ ν. αὐτοῦ LXX Jn. 1.3; λαλῶν τὰ ν. Diph. 43.21; ἔδωκα αὐτῷ τὰ ν. Sammelb. 3553; τὸ δὲ ν. διωρθωσάμεθα ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν PCair.Zen. 52.13 (iii B. C.); συνέβη ναῦλον ἡμῖν προσάγεσθαι τοῦ . . πλοίου we were charged for the hire of the boat, ib. 368.27 (iii B. C.).

data.quote: τῆς πόλεως ναῦλον τελούσης τοῖς ἄγουσι τοὺς λίθους
τὸ δὲ ν. διωρθωσάμεθα ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν

children.definition: ν. πλοίου name of a tax paid for the use of state-provided boats, BGU 645.16 (ii A. D.), PSI 8.960.15 (iv A. D.); ἀποδιαγράψειν τὸ συναχθησόμενον ν. ἐπὶ τὴν βασιλικὴν τράπεζαν PTheb.Bank 12.7 (ii B. C.), cf. Sammelb. 6954.

data.quote: ἀποδιαγράψειν τὸ συναχθησόμενον ν. ἐπὶ τὴν βασιλικὴν τράπεζαν

children.definition: ναῦλα, τά, = ἐφόδια, Hsch. (ascribed to Aeschylus by Cyr. in cod. Laur.57.39).
lie in a harbour or creek, esp. lie in wait in order to sally out on passing ships, abs. in Hdt. 7.189, 192, 8.6, E. IA 249 (lyr.):— Med., ναυλοχεῖσθαί τινι D.H. 1.44 (s. v.l.).
lie in wait for, Th. 7.4.
anchorage, esp. of pirates, App. Mith. 92.
Ar. Fr. 78.

affording a safe anchorage, epith. of a harbour, λιμένες δʼ ἔνι ν. αὐτῇ Od. 4.846; ν. ἐς λιμένα 10.141; ν. λιπὼν ἕδρας S. Aj. 460; ὦ ν. καὶ πετραῖα θερμὰ λουτρά ye hot springs by the haven and from the rock (unless ναύλοχα is Subst.), Id. Tr. 633 (lyr.); Ἀχαιῶν ναύλοχοι περιπτυχαί E. Hec. 1015: Sup. ναυλοχώτατος λιμήν Ph. 1.181, cf. 352.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., station for ships, haven, Suid.: also neut. pl. ναύλοχα Plu. Sollert. 2.984b; cf. supr.
let oneʼs ship for hire, Plu. QConv. 2.707c, OGI 572.42 ( Myra), PLond. 3.948.1 (iii A. D.):— Med., hire a ship, Plb. 31.12.11, Ath. 12.521a, PFlor. 305.4 (iv A. D.).
for hire, πλοῖον POxy. 276.7 (i A.D.); κτήνη, ὄνοι, PRein. 54.4 (iii/iv A.D.), PFlor. 238.7 (iii A.D.).
for chartering of ships: -κή (sc. συγγραφή), ἡ, POxy. 643 (ii A.D.).
Hsch.

fight by sea, Hdt. 7.143, al.; τινι with one, Id. 2.161; ἐναντία τῇ πόλει And. 1.101; πρός τινας X. HG 2.1.14; περὶ πατρίδος Hdt. 8.57; ν. τὴν περὶ τῶν κρεῶν, i.e. to be in the battle of Arginusae (v. κρέας 2), Ar. Ra. 191; μὰ τοὺς ἐν Σαλαμῖνι ναυμαχήσαντας D. 18.208, cf. Pl. Mx. 241b, 241d.
do battle with, κακοῖς τοσούτοις Ar. V. 479.
wish to fight by sea, Th. 8.79.
one must fight by sea, Arist. Rh. 1376a2.

sea-fight, Hdt. 6.14, al., Th. 1.13, etc.; ν. ποιέεσθαι Hdt. 8.49; ναυμαχίῃ κρατήσας, ἑσσωθέντες, Id. 3.39, 6.92; ναυμαχίᾳ νικᾶν X. HG 1.6.2; ναυμαχίας νενικήκατε ib. 1.1.28; ναυμαχίαν ἀπώσασθαί τινα in a sea-fight, Th. 1.32; πολλὰς ν. νεναυμαχηκώς Lys. 7.41; τὴν περὶ Σαλαμῖνα ν. τῶν Ἑλλήνων πρὸς τοὺς βαρβάρους Pl. Lg. 707b.

data.quote: τὴν περὶ Σαλαμῖνα ν. τῶν Ἑλλήνων πρὸς τοὺς βαρβάρους

children.definition: of or for a sea-fight, ξυστὰ ν. pikes for sea-battles, Il. 15.389, cf. 677; δόρατα ν. Hdt. 7.89, cf. D.Chr. 11.117, Opp. H. 5.301, C. 2.62.

children.label: II
children.definition: ναυμάχος, Act., fighting at sea, AP 7.741 ( Crin.), Ath. 4.154f, IG 3.1202.146 (iii A. D.).

definition: ναῦον, τό, perh. an Egyptian measure of length, PCair.Zen. 383 (iii B. C.).

children.definition: Naupactus, on the north of the gulf of Corinth, Th. 2.91:— Adj. Ναυπάκτιος, α, ον, A. Supp. 262, etc.
shipyard, D.S. 19.58; cf. ναυπήγιον.

to be a shipbuilder, build ships, Ar. Pl. 513, Pl. Alc. 1.107c:—more freq. in Med., πλοῖα, νέας ναυπηγέεσθαι, build oneself ships, get them built, Hdt. 2.96, 6.46, cf. Pl. l.c.; ἐπί τινι against others, Hdt. 1.27; ἐναυπηγοῦντο νεῶν στόλον Th. 1.31; τριήρεις ἐναυπηγησάμεθα And. 3.5, cf. Th. 6.90, D. 17.28: pf. νεναυπήγημαι in med. sense, D.S. 20.16:— Pass., of ships, to be built, Th. 1.13 (v.l. ἐνναυπηγηθῆναι); ὁπόσα ἂν οἰκοδομηθῇ ἢ ναυπηγηθῇ X. Vect. 4.35, cf. HG 1.3.17, Plu. Fort.Rom. 2.321d.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., contrive, ‘engineer’, τὰ πάντα νεναυπηγημένη ἐπὶ ταῖς Ῥωμαίων τύχαις J. AJ 19.2.4.

data.quote: τὰ πάντα νεναυπηγημένη ἐπὶ ταῖς Ῥωμαίων τύχαις

children.definition: shipbuilding, τέχναι Man. 4.323.

definition: ναυπηγήσιμος, ον, also η, ον Pl. Lg. 705c, Str. 14.5.3:—

children.definition: useful in shipbuilding, of timber, ἴδη Hdt. 5.23; ξύλα Th. 4.108, 7.25, X. HG 5.2.16, SIG 135.10 ( Olynthus, iv B.C.); ὕλη Pl. l.c., Str. l.c.; χώρα Philostr. Her. 19.20.
= sq., Sammelb. 6994.30 (iii B.C.), Asp. in EN 143.13, Hsch. s.v. ξυλοδωνίη.
shipbuilding, Hdt. 1.27; ν. ἁρμόζειν to practise shipbuilding, E. Cyc. 460; ναυπηγίαν τριηρῶν παρασκευάζεσθαι Th. 4.108, cf. D.S. 19.58.
for shipbuilding, πέλεκυς Luc. DMort. 20[10].9: ἡ -κή (with or without τέχνη), art of shipbuilding, Arist. EN 1094a8, Gal. Thras. 5:
Subst., τὸ ναυπηγικόν Plu. Fat. 2.571f; contract for building a ship, PLond. 3.1164h14 (iii A.D.).
shipbuilderʼs yard, dockyard, Ar. Av. 1157, Inscr.Délos 363.41, 365.20 (iii B. C.).
shipbuilder, shipwright, Th. 1.13, Pl. R. 333c, al., PPetr. 2 p.61 (iii B. C.), PCair.Zen. 270.8 (iii B.C.):—written ναϝυπηγός IG 1(2).672; ναπηγός ib. 428.
Nauplia in Argolis, Hdt. 6.76, etc.; Ναυπλιεύς, έως, ὁ, a Nauplian, Str. 8.6.14:— Adj. Ναύπλιος, α, ον, E. Or. 369; or Ναυπλίειος, ib. 54.
shell-fish, Peripl.M.Rubr. 17; f.l. for ναυτίλος, Artem. 2.14.

definition: ναύποδα μακρόποδα, Hsch. (false division of ταναύποδα).

children.definition: ship-frequented, ἀκταί A. Eu. 10; λίμνης στόμα A.R. 4.1546.

children.label: II
children.definition: ναυπόρος, = ναυσίπορος II.2, πλάτη E. Tr. 877.
burning ships, EM 598.43.
ruling ships or the sea, δαίμων Pi. Pae. 6.130.

definition: ναῦρα ἢ ναυρόν· ὄγκος, Hsch. ναυρίζειν· καταμωκᾶσθαι, Id.

children.definition: temple-guard, IG 14.401 ( Messana). (Cf. ναρούς: prob. from ναός and -hορϝο- ( ἐρύω B), cf. θυρωρός, etc.)

ship, Hom., etc. (but rare in non-literary Hellenistic Greek, once in NT, Act. Ap. 27.41, πλοῖον being generally used); ἐν νήεσσι or ἐν νηυσίν at the ships, i.e. in the camp formed by the ships drawn up on shore, Il. 2.688, 11.659; νῆες μακραί ships of war, built long and taper for speed, Th. 1.41, etc.; opp. νῆες στρογγύλαι round-built merchant- ships, Hdt. 1.163, etc.; νέες alone, = τριήρεις, opp. πεντηκόντεροι, Id. 8.1; νῆες κεναί, i.e. without fighting men in them, D. 3.5; ναῦς μακρά collective for μακραί, A. Pers. 380.— Att. decl. ναῦς, νεώς, νηΐ, ναῦν, dual gen. νεοῖν, pl. νῆες, νεῶν (νηῶν is v.l. in Lys. 13.15), ναυσί, ναῦς; in later writers, nom. pl. ναῦς, acc. pl. νῆας, D.S. 13.13, Plb. 5.2.4, etc., cf. Phryn. 147:— Ep. νηῦς, νηός, νηΐ, νῆα, pl. νῆες, νηῶν, νηυσί or νήεσσι, νῆας (but also gen. and acc. sg. νεός, νέα [the latter as monosyll. in Od. 9.283], pl. νέες, νεῶν, νέεσσι, νέας); Ep. gen. and dat. pl. ναῦφι, -φιν, Il. 2.794, 16.281, Od. 14.498; in late Ep., nom. νῆυς dub. l. in Mosch. 2.104, cf. EM 440.17; acc. sg. and pl. νηῦν, νηῦς, A.R. 1.1358, Herod. 2.3, Dem. Bith. 4.6: Hdn.Gr. 1.401, 2.675, 553 also gives νεῦς, νεΐ ( v.l. in Hdt. 7.184), and νευσί ( Hp. Ep. 27, Sammelb. 5829):— Ion. νηῦς, νεός, νηΐ, νέα, pl. νέες, νεῶν, νηυσί ( νηυσίν Epigr. in IG 12(8).683 ( Thasos, vi/v B. C.)), νέας (but νηός Archil. (?) in PLit.Lond. 54; νηός is freq. in codd. of Hdt., νηῶν 7.160):— Dor. ναῦς ( νᾶς Hdn.Gr. 1.400), νᾱός Pi. P. 4.185, al., νᾱΐ Id. O. 13.54, al. ( νᾷ perh. to be read in Alcm. 23 iii 27), ναῦν Pi. P. 4.245, Fr. 234 ( νᾶν Hdn.Gr. 1.328, νᾶα B. 16.89); pl. νᾶες Pi. O. 12.4, al., ναῶν Id. P. 1.74, ναυσί, ναυσίν, Id. N. 7.29, P. 3.68 ( νάεσσι ib. 4.56), νᾶας f.l. in Theoc. 22.17:— Aeol. sg. gen. νᾶος, dat. νᾶϊ, pl. dat. νάεσσι, Alc. 19, 18, 79, gen. νᾱων Id. Supp. 12.9, Sapph. Supp. 5.2:—Trag. commonly use Dor. forms in lyr., Att. in dialogue (but sts. ναός, ναῶν, A. Th. 62, Pers. 340, etc.); the Ep. forms νηός S. Fr. 761, νηῶν E. IT 1485, νῆας A. Supp. 744 (lyr.), νηυσίν Id. Pers. 370 (cod. M) are prob. corrupt. (Cf. Skt. naús, Lat. nāvis, etc.)
IG 4.823.12 ( Troezen), Hsch.

carry by sea, ἐκ γᾶς E. Tr. 162 (lyr.); ἐς γῆν πατρίδα ναυσθλώσων νεκρόν Id. Supp. 1037:— Med., take with one by sea, ναυσθλοῦσθε παῖδα Id. IT 1487:— Pass., go by sea, ναυσθλοῦμαι Id. Tr. 677; πελάγεσιν ναυσθλούμενος Id. Hel. 1210; οὐ ναυσθλώσομαι Ar. Pax 126.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be visited by ships, γῆ ναυσθλωθήσεται Lyc. 1415.
squeamishness, Hsch.
pf. νεναυσίακα BGU 1097.4 (i A. D.).
Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 33.7, Man. 1.323, Hsch. s.v. βαρυδάνιν.
living by the sea, Alciphr. 1.12 (pr.n.).
ship-speeding, οὖρος Orph. H. 74.10.
famed for ships, famous by sea, κούρῃ ναυσικλειτοῖο Δύμαντος Od. 6.22, cf. h.Ap. 31, 219.
= foreg., Φαίηκες, Φοίνικες, Od. 7.39, 15.415; fem. ναυσικλυτάν Pi. N. 5.9.
feeling nausea or disgust, Nic. Al. 83 (v.l. ναυτ-), 482.
anchor, Luc. Lex. 15.
navigable, Hdt. 1.189, 193, 5.52, Arist. Mete. 351a18, D.H. 3.44.
ship-footed, of islanders, Hsch., Eust. 1515.27.
ship-wafting, αὔρα E. Ph. 1712 (lyr.).
traversed by ships, navigable, of a river, X. An. 2.2.3, Arist. Mir. 846b31, Hld. 10.5, Philostr. VA 3.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: ναυσιπόρος, ον, Act., passing in a ship, seafaring, στρατιά E. Rh. 48 (lyr.).
causing a ship to pass, πλάται ν. ship-speeding oars, Id. IA 172 (lyr.).
lamentable loss of the ships, Pi. P. 1.72.
ship-destroying, αὖραι Tim. Pers. 144.
carried by ship, seafaring, ἄνδρες Pi. P. 1.33.
vomiting: hence φλεβῶν ν. gushing of blood from the veins, Hp. Fract. 11 (pl.).
occupied by ships, Sch. Opp. H. 5.461.

definition: ναῦσσον, τό, name of a tax, SIG 4.6 ( Cyzicus, vi B.C.), 1000.1 ( Cos, i B.C.).—In SIG 4 -σσ- is written T.

children.definition: harbour, anchorage, roadstead, Th. 3.6, E. Rh. 602 (pl.):—more freq. ναύ-σταθμος, ὁ, Plb. 5.19.6, D.S. 27.12, Plu. Nic. 16, etc.; hence of ships assembled in a roadstead, Id. Arist. 22, Lys. 5.
Sammelb. 1207.

definition: ναυστολέω, fut. -ήσω. E. Supp. 474: pf. νεναυστόληκα ( συν-) S. Ph. 550:

children.label: I
children.definition: carry or convey by sea, δάμαρτα E. Or. 741 (troch.): metaph., ἴδια ν. ἐπικώμια providing matter for their own praise, Pi. N. 6.32, cf. Luc. Lex. 2:— Pass., with fut. Med. -ήσομαι, go by sea, E. Tr. 1048; τὰ ναυστολούμενα Id. Fr. 492.6; τηλικοῦτον πέλαγος ναυστοληθείς D.S. 4.13.

guide, steer, metaph., κυμάτων ἄτερ πόλιν σὴν ναυστολήσεις E. Supp. l.c.; τὼ πτέρυγε ποῖ ναυστολεῖς; whither pliest thou thy wings? Ar. Av. 1229; ὁ ναυστολῶν . . εἰμʼ ἐγὼ τὰς συμφοράς the enterprise is mine, E. IT 599.

children.label: II
children.definition: go by ship, sail, ἐξ Ἰλίου S. Ph. 245; πρὸς οἴκους ἀπʼ Ἰλίου E. Tr. 77: metaph., διὰ πόνων ἐναυστόλουν Id. Fr. 821.2.

children.label: III
children.definition: approach by sea, ἵπποισιν ἢ κύμβαισι ν. χθόνα; S. Fr. 127 (by zeugma), cf. E. Med. 682, Hipp. 36, Cyc. 106.— Poet. and later Prose.
= sq., πόντου ναυστολήμαθʼ E. Supp. 209.
going by sea, naval expedition, E. Andr. 795 (lyr.), Str. 16.2.23.
take as a passenger, metaph. of Ἀχέρων, CIL 8.21445 (Caesarea Mauret.).
navis dispositor, Gloss.: also, in pl., pilotage dues, ib.
dispatched or equipped as a ship, crossing the water, A. Th. 858.
naval affairs, σύλληψις τῶν εἰς τὴν ν. OGI 90.17 ( Rosetta, ii B.C.), cf. PRev.Laws 85.6 (iii B.C.).
seaman, sailor, Il. 19.375, Sapph. Supp. 9.8, Pi. P. 4.188, Pl. Plt. 302a, etc.: as Adj., ν. ὅμιλος E. Hec. 921 (lyr.); by sea, opp. πεζός (by land), A. Pers. 719 (troch.).

children.label: II
children.definition: passenger by sea, ναύτην ἄγειν τινά S. Ph. 901: metaph., συμποσίου ναῦται mates in the drinking bout, Dionys.Eleg. 5.
seasickness, or generally, nausea, Arist. PA 664b13 (pl.), Aret. SA 1.5, 2.2, Alciphr. 2.4, Jul. Or. 6.190d: pl., Porph. Gaur. 8.1.
disgust, Semon. l.c.

definition: ναυτιάω, mostly in pres. and impf. ( aor., Luc. Tox. 19, Gal. 16.665, Phryn. 172: fut., Aristo Stoic. 1.89):—

children.definition: suffer from seasickness or nausea, Ar. Th. 882, Pl. Tht. 191a, Lg. 639b, Arist. Pr. 868a6, D. Fr. 30, Plu. Per. 33; ταῦτα δʼ ἐστὶ πλεῖν ἢ ναυτιᾶν Com.Adesp. 637; ἐναυτίων Luc. Nec. 4.

data.quote: ταῦτα δʼ ἐστὶ πλεῖν ἢ ναυτιᾶν

children.definition: to be disgusted, Demetr. Eloc. 15, Phryn. l.c.

definition: ναυτιεύς, derivative of ναύτης, sine expl., EM 63.55.

children.definition: of or for a ship, seafaring, naval, ὁ ν. στρατός Hdt. 7.100, 203, etc.; opp. ὁ πεζός, Id. 8.1; ν. λεώς A. Pers. 383; στόλος S. Ph. 561; ν. ἐρείπια wrecks of ships, A. Ag. 660; ἑδώλια S. Aj. 1277; σκάφη ib. 1278; ν. πόλεμος And. 4.12; ν. ἀστρολογία Arist. APo. 79a1; ἔγγαια καὶ ναυτικά property on land and sea, PEleph. 1.13 (iv B.C.); ν. ἀναρχία among the seamen, E. Hec. 607; τὸ ν. crew, Hp. Ep. 14; but usu. navy, fleet, Hdt. 7.97, 160, Ar. Eq. 1063, Th. 1.36, etc.; ἡ -κή Hdt. 7.161.
skilled in seamanship, nautical, ναυτικοὶ ἐγένοντο became a naval power, Th. 1.18, cf. 7.21; ναυτικός, ὁ, = ναύτης, POxy. 929.8 (ii/iii A.D.).
ἡ-κή (sc. τέχνη) navigation, seamanship, Hdt. 8.1, etc.; τὰ -κά Pl. Alc. 1.124e: τὰ -κά, also, naval affairs, sea-power, Th. 4.75, X. HG 1.6.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: ναυτικόν, τό, perh. pilotʼs fee, POxy. 522.15 (ii A.D.); but usu.

children.label: b
children.definition: money borrowed or lent on bottomry, in full, ν. χρήματα Lys. 32.7: mostly in pl., ν. ἐκδεδομένα ib. 6; ναυτικὸν ἀνελέσθαι to take it up, borrow it, D. 50.17; ναυτικοῖς ἐργάζεσθαι Id. 33.4: in sg., X. Vect. 3.9; also ν. τόκος D.L. 6.99. Adv. -κῶς, δανείζειν Id. 7.13.

definition: ναυτιλέῳ, dat. sg., perh. Coan form of Ναυτίλῳ,

children.definition: The Sailor, as place-name, SIG 1000.11 ( Cos, i B.C.).
sailing, seamanship, Od. 8.253, Hes. Op. 618, Pl. R. 527d, al.
voyage, Hdt. 4.145, Hp. Aph. 4.14: and in pl., ναυτιλίῃσι μακρῇσι ἐπιθέσθαι Hdt. 1.1, cf. 163; ναυτιλίῃσι χρέεσθαι Id. 2.43, cf. Pi. N. 3.22, I. 4(3).57.
ship, πολύσκαλμος ν. AP 7.295.4 ( Leon.).

definition: ναυτίλλομαι, only pres. and impf. (exc. aor. subj. ναυτίλεται [ῑ] Od. 4.672 (prob.), inf. ναυτίλασθαι [ῑ] D.C. 56.3):—

children.definition: sail, go by sea, ναυτίλεται εἵνεκα πατρός Od. l.c., cf. 14.246, Hdt. 1.163, 2.5, al., S. Ant. 717, E. Fr. 793; ν. τὴν [θάλασσαν] sail on, navigate, Hdt. 1.202; ναυτιλίαν ναυτίλλεσθαι Pl. R. 551c.
κενῷ [τῷ ὀστράκῳ] ν. Arist. HA 622b9.
Philostr. Im. 1.9.
seaman, sailor, Hdt. 2.43, A. Pr. 468, S. Aj. 1146: rare in Com., Nausicr. 1.2, 2.10.
Adj. ναύτῐλος, ον, of a ship, ν. σέλματα A. Ag. 1442; ν. πλάτη E. Fr. 846.

children.label: II
children.definition: paper nautilus, Argonauta argo, a cephalopod mollusc fabled to sail by spreading its membranous arms, Arist. HA 525a21, 622b5, cf. Call. Epigr. 6.3, Opp. H. 1.340, Ael. NA 9.34.
bane of sailors, Lyc. 650.
ναύτης, γυναῖκες Theopomp.Com. 79.
nauseous, sickening, Dsc. 1.40, Antyll. ap. Orib. 4.11.6, Plu. Sanit. 2.127a, 128d; τὸ ν. Gal. 6.678.
disposed to nausea, διάθεσις Id. 13.122, 156. Adv. -δῶς, ἔχειν Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 5.27.22.
judges of the admiralty-court, IG 1(2).41.4, Lys. 17.5, Luc. DMeretr. 2.2: they also took cognizance of γραφαὶ ξενίας, Cratin. 233, cf. Ar. Fr. 225.
take on board passengers or cargo, PLond. 3.1164h19 (iii A.D.): metaph., Κύπριν ν. AP 9.415 ( Antiphil.).
collecting seamen, Str. 8.6.15.
sailor boy, Hp. Epid. 2.1.12.

definition: ναύτρια, ἡ, fem. of ναύτης, as if from *ναυτήρ, Ar. Fr. 825.

children.definition: ship-devouring, wrecking, Lyc. 1095.
shipwreck, loss of ships, AP 7.73 ( Tull.Gem.): pl., Man. 1.324.
shipwrecked, ν. στολή, πέπλοι, the garb of shipwrecked men, E. Hel. 1382, 1539.

definition: ναύφρακτος, Att. ναύφαρκτος Phot. ( ναύφ[ . . . .] ος IG 1(2).296.30), ον: ( φράσσω):—

children.definition: ship-fenced, Ἰάνων ν. Ἄρης, of the Greeks at Salamis, A. Pers. 951 (lyr.); so ν. ὅμιλος ib. 1029 (lyr.); στράτευμα E. IA 1259; στρατός Ar. Eq. 567; ναύφαρκτον βλέπειν to look like a ship of war, Id. Ach. 95.
guard a ship, Eust. 1562.36.
one who keeps watch on board ship, Ar. Fr. 372.

children.label: II
children.definition: IG 42(1).402 (pl., Epid., ii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Id., Phot. ναυών, ῶνος, ὁ, ( ναῦς) = νεών, νεώριον, Hsch.
naphtha (Persian naft), Dsc. 1.73, D.C. 36.3a:—also νάφθας, ὁ, Str. 16.1.15; acc. νάφθαν LXX Da. 3.64; gen. νάφθα Str. l.c., Plu. Alex. 35.
linen thread, Hsch. ναχαδόν· σαθρόν, Id. ναχειλές, = foreg., Id.

definition: νάω, only pres. and impf., Att. contr. νᾷ S. Fr. 5, part. νῶντας Phot.:—

children.definition: flow, ἐν δὲ κρήνη νάει Od. 6.292; καὶ φρείατα μακρὰ νάουσιν Il. 21.197; ὄφρʼ ἂν ὕδωρ τε νάῃ Epigr. ap. Pl. Phdr. 264d; οἴνῳ Ἁχελῷος ἆρα νᾷ S. l.c.; ὕδατι νᾶε was running with . . , A.R. 1.1146; νᾶεν φόνῳ Call. Dian. 224:— Pass., to be watered, νᾱομένοισι τόποις Nic. Fr. 74.58. [ ᾰ in Hom. and presupposed by νᾷ, νῶντας, cf. ἀέναος: ᾱ v.l. in Od. 9.222, always in late Ep. exc. Euph. 23; ναῖον (so Aristarch. and some codd.) δʼ ὀρῷ ἄγγεα πάντα is prob. correct in Od. l.c., cf. ἔναιεν ἐν ἅλμῃ (with pun on ναίω dwell) Matro Conv. 77, and ναιομένοισι ( νεομ- codd.) shd. perh. be read in Nic. l.c.] (Cf. ἔννυθεν, ναύω, νόα, Skt. snaúti ( pf. part. Pass. snutás) ‘drip’, MIr. snuadh ‘river’, etc.: νάω [ᾰ] from snǎw-w, ναίω and νάω [ᾱ] from snǎw-yw.)
newly or lately told, φάτις A. Ch. 736.

definition: νεαγενής, f.l. for νεογενής in E. IA 1623 (unless scanned as trisyll.).
νεάζω, impf. ἐνέαζον Agath. 5.15: aor. 1 inf. νεάσαι AP 11.256 ( Lucill.), elsewh. only pres.: ( νέος):—

children.definition: to be young or new, τὸ νεάζον youth, S. Tr. 144; νεάζων thinking or acting like a youth, E. Ph. 713; ν. τῷ τρόπῳ Men. 749: metaph., to be full of youthful spirit, φιλεῖ δὲ τίκτειν ὕβρις παλαιὰ νεάζουσαν ὕβριν A. Ag. 764 (lyr.), cf. Supp. 105 (lyr.); νεάζειν ἀρχόμενος Alciphr. 1.28.

data.quote: φιλεῖ δὲ τίκτειν ὕβρις παλαιὰ νεάζουσαν ὕβριν

children.definition: to be the younger of two, ὁ μὲν νεάζων S. OC 374.
grow or be young again, AP l.c.; ὅπως γηράσκων νεάζῃ τοῖς ἀγαθοῖς Epicur. Ep. 3p.59U.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be renewed, στέμμα . . ἐκ πατρὸς παιδὶ νεαζόμενον AP 15.6.

children.label: IV
children.definition: νεάζομεν· ἀφικνούμεθα, Id.
Neaera, daughter of Oceanus:—hence Νεαιρήϊδες ἵπποι, Hsch.
newly taken, θήρ A. Ag. 1063; πόλις ib. 1065; βούβαλις Id. Fr. 330.
newly-whetted, νεακόνητον αἷμα χειροῖν ἔχων S. El. 1394 (lyr.); cf. αἷμα II fin.
newly grown or produced, Opp. H. 1.692.
newly-ground, Sch. Nic. Al. 410.
newly caught, Suid., Hsch., Ammon. Diff. p.95 V.

fresh, not tired, of persons and animals, ἕως νεαλής ἐστιν αὐτὴν τὴν ἀκμήν Ar. Fr. 361 ; ἵπποι νεαλεῖς, opp. ἀπειρηκότες, X. Cyr. 8.6.17; -έστεροι ὄντες Pl. Plt. 265b; freq. of soldiers, ἀκμαῖοι καὶ ν. Plb. 3.73.5, cf. 10.14.3; ἀήττητοι καὶ ν. Plu. Ant. 39 (hence of reserve troops, App. BC 1.58); ν. καὶ πρόθυμος Plu. QConv. 2.669a; -έστερος ἐπεισελθεῖν Luc. Merc.Cond. 26, cf. Alex. 16.

data.quote: ἕως νεαλής ἐστιν αὐτὴν τὴν ἀκμήν

children.definition: νέος, ἅλς A) freshly salted, opp. τεταριχευμένος, D. 25.61 (metaph.); τυρός Archig. ap. Gal. 12.808; κρέας Gal. 6.528; of a dead body, Luc. Nec. 15; νεαλὲς γάλα Nic. Al. 364 ( νεαρόν cod. opt.).

children.label: II
children.definition: young, = νεαρός, μόσχος ib. 358. [ ᾰ only in Nic. ll.cc.]
newly caught, Hdt. 9.120 (v.l. νεοάλωτος).
culta nova, Gloss.
newly milked, Paul.Aeg. 4.1.
IG 12(2).81.1 (Mytil.), Milet. 3 No.152.37 ( ii B.C.; νεναμέρα lapis).
A.D. Adv. 160.8 ( νεᾶν codd.), Suid. s.v. νεᾶνις, Eust. 335.15; cf. ξυνάν.

definition: νέανδρος, ον: ἀλκῇ ν. in battle

children.definition: a young warrior, Lyc. 1345.
spirited, audacious act, Ph. 1.258, 2.128, cf. Hdn. Epim. 265, Suid.; contr. fr. νεανιεία (q.v.).
new-blown, Nic. Al. 609; αἶνος IG 3.716.16.

definition: νεανίας, ου, Ep. and Ion. νεηνίης, εω, ὁ, dat. pl. νεανίοις IG 9(2).205.25 ( Phthiotis, iii B.C.): ( νεάν):—

children.definition: young man, Hom. (only in Od.) always with ἀνήρ, νεηνίῃ ἀνδρὶ ἐοικώς Od. 10.278; ἄνδρες κοιμήσαντο νεηνίαι 14.524; παῖδες νεηνίαι Hdt. 1.61, cf. 7.99; ν. γαμβρός Pi. O. 7.4; τέκτονες κώμων ν. Id. N. 3.5: without a Subst. in Hdt. 1.37, 43, S. OC 335, El. 750, E. Alc. 698, X. Mem. 3.1.2, etc.

a youth in character, i.e. either in good sense, impetuous, active, E. Ion 1041, cf. Ar. V. 1333, X. Cyr. 1.3.6, D. 18.313; or in bad sense, hot-headed, wilful, headstrong, E. Supp. 580; ἓν μὲν τοίνυν τοῦτο . . πολίτευμα τοῦ νεανίου τούτου D. 18.136, cf. Pl. Sph. 239d.

data.quote: ἓν μὲν τοίνυν τοῦτο . . πολίτευμα τοῦ νεανίου τούτου

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., youthful, νεανίαι τὰς ὄψεις Lys. 10.29.

new, young, fresh, νεανίαις ὤμοισι E. Hel. 1562; ν. θώρακα καὶ βραχίονα Id. HF 1095; ἄρτος Ar. Lys. 1207; ν. λόγοι rash, wilful words, E. Alc. 679. [ νεανιῶν is trisyll. in Ar. V. 1069; cf. νεανικός.]
youthful spirit, Ph. 2.306; cf. νεανεία.
youthful, i.e. spirited or (in bad sense) wanton, act or word, Pl. R. 390a, Luc. Herm. 33, etc.; of an argument, bold attempt, Simp. in Ph. 1169.9.

definition: νεανιεύομαι ( Act. only in Hsch.), fut. -εύσομαι D. 19.242: aor. ἐνεανιευσάμην Id. 21.69:— Pass. (v. infr.):—

children.definition: to be a youth, Ph. 1.303, Poll. 2.20.

children.label: II
children.definition: act like a hot-headed youth, wilfully or wantonly, swagger, Ar. Fr. 827, Lys. Fr. 324 S.; ν. εἰς τοὺς πολίτας behave so towards . . , Isoc. 20.17, cf. Hyp. Eux. 27; ἐν τοῖς λόγοις Pl. Grg. 482c; νεανιευσάμενος εἰπεῖν with youthful insolence, Plu. Cic. 1:— Pass., ἐφʼ ἅπασι τοῖς ἑαυτῷ νενεανιευμένοις to all his wanton acts, D. 21.18; τὰ ἐν τῇ βουλῇ νεανιευθέντα Plu. Mar. 29.

make youthful, i.e. bold, promises, c. Adj. neut., ν. τοιοῦτον, ὡς . . D. 19.194; οὐδʼ ἐνεανιεύσατο τοιοῦτον οὐδέν Id. 21.69; μέχρι τοῦ λόγου ν. Luc. Bis Acc. 21: c. inf., undertake with youthful spirit, Plu. Dem. 3.
to be youthful, Eup. 109.
youthful, ῥώμη Ar. V. 1067: mostly of youthful qualities : hence,
fresh, active, vigorous, fine, νεανικώτατε Id. Eq. 611; κρέας ν. a fine large piece, Id. Pl. 1137; λοπάς Alex. 188.2; of trees, Thphr. HP 5.1.11 ( Comp.); -ώτερα ἀγαθά more splendid, Pl. R. 363c.

high-spirited, impetuous, gay, τὸ νεανικώτατον the most dashing feat, Ar. V. 1205; ἀρχὴ καλὴ καὶ ν. Pl. R. 563e; γενναῖον καὶ ν. ἔρωτα Id. Ly. 204e; ν. τε καὶ μεγαλοπρεπεῖς τὰς διανοίας Id. R. 503c; μέγα καὶ ν. φρόνημα D. 3.32; οὐ γὰρ ἡγεῖτο λαμπρὸν οὐδὲ ν. Id. 21.131, cf. 201.

data.quote: ν. τε καὶ μεγαλοπρεπεῖς τὰς διανοίας
οὐ γὰρ ἡγεῖτο λαμπρὸν οὐδὲ ν.

children.definition: headstrong, insolent, τὸ ν. τοῦ λόγου Pl. Grg. 508d; ἢ σοῦ τις -ώτερος ib. 509a; δημοκρατία ἡ -ωτάτη Arist. Pol. 1296a4.

vehement, mighty, ψῦξις -ωτάτη Hp. VM 16; αἱμορραγία Id. Prorrh. 1.134; φόβος E. Hipp. 1204; βούλευμα Id. Fr. 185.6: freq. in later Prose, ἐπιθυμία ν. Arist. EN 1148a21; βροντή Id. HA 602b23; νόσημα ib. 602b29; χειμών Thphr. Ign. 17.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. -κῶς in a youthful manner, ἐστείλαμεν ἑαυτοὺς ν. X.Eph. 5.1.
vigorously, Ar. Pax 898; ν. βοηθεῖν τινι Pl. Tht. 168c; βιαίως καὶ ν. Dsc. 1.56; of things, Ph. Bel. 78.29: Comp. -κωτέρως, ἀγαθός Phld. Rh. 2.272 S.
violently, wantonly, τύπτειν, τωθάζειν, Ar. V. 1307, 1362; ν. ἀκόλαστος Phld. Acad.Ind. p.47 M.
excessively, ν. τρομώδεα Hp. Prorrh. 1.9; ν. προσπεφυκέναι to be firmly attached to . . , Arist. HA 530a15. [ νεανικήν is trisyll. in Ar. V. 1067; cf. νεανίας.]
youthfulness, Sext. Ps. 9.1.

definition: νεᾶνις, Ep. and Ion. νεῆνις ( contr. νῆνις Anacr. 14.3, CIG 7629 (vase), Kretschmer Griech.Vaseninschr. p.144, EM 448.29), ῐδος, ἡ, acc. -ιδα A. Pr. 704, -ιν E. Cyc. 179:—

children.definition: girl, maiden, Il. 18.418, Pi. P. 9.31, A. l.c., Eu. 958 (lyr.), S. Ant. 784 (lyr.), E. l.c., al., A.R. 1.843, Lyr. Alex.Adesp. 26; of a young married woman, E. Andr. 192; παρθενικὴ ν. Od. 7.20.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., youthful, χεῖρες, ἧβαι, E. Ba. 745, Ion 477 (lyr.).
new, βίβλος AP 4.3b75 ( Agath.).—Poet. word, but freq. in LXX, Ex. 2.8, al.

definition: νεανισκάριον, τό, Dim. of νεανίσκος, Arr. Epict. 2.16.29.

children.definition: hold office of νεανισκάρχης, IG 3.765, 1098.
official in charge of ἔφηβοι, IG 3.1162.8, Delph. 3(1).238, IPE 2.440, al. ( Tanais), Supp.Epigr. 2.620 ( Teos), BSA 29.23 ( Sparta, ii A.D.), Philol. 11.293 ( Smyrna).
= Lat. Juvenalia, D.C. 61.19, 67.14.
to be in oneʼs youth, Eup. 29, Posidipp. 9; ν. ἐν τοῖς ἐφήβοις X. Cyr. 1.2.15, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.12b.

youth, young man, IG 1(2).374.162, al., Hdt. 4.72, 112, Pl. Smp. 211d, Arist. Pol. 1303b21, Anon.Hist.( FGrH 160) p.887 J., etc.; ν. τὸ εἶδος (nisi leg. νεανικός) X. HG 3.3.5; in Hdt. 3.53 the same youth is called both νεηνίης and νεηνίσκος; but in Antipho 3.4.6 and 8 the same person is called ν. and μειράκιον, and the eldest son of Socrates is called νεανίσκος X. Mem. 2.2.1, but μειράκιον Pl. Ap. 34d; ἔν τε παισὶ καὶ ν. καὶ ἐν ἀνδράσι Id. R. 413e; παῖς εἴκοσι ἔτεα, νεηνίσκος εἴκοσι, νεηνίης εἴκοσι, γέρων εἴκοσι Pythag. ap. D.L. 8.10, cf. Hp. Hebd. 5: more freq. than νεανίας in later Gr., Wilcken Chr. 30i4 (iii/ii B.C.), Plb. 1.36.12, Ev.Matt. 19.20, etc.

data.quote: ἔν τε παισὶ καὶ ν. καὶ ἐν ἀνδράσι
παῖς εἴκοσι ἔτεα, νεηνίσκος εἴκοσι, νεηνίης εἴκοσι, γέρων εἴκοσι

children.definition: ὁ ἐμὸς ν. my young man, i.e. servant, Luc. Alex. 53; perh. also, PCair.Zen. 18.6 (iii B.C.), Ev.Marc. 14.51: pl., dub. sens., PCair.Zen. 153 ( iii B.C., written νενίσκοις).
Theognost. Can. 126.

definition: νέαξ ( Ion. νέηξ Call. Fr. 78), ᾱκος, ὁ,

children.definition: Nicopho 10, cf. Poll. 2.11.
singing youthfully, AP 7.13 ( Leon. or Mel.).

new city, pr. n. of several cities, Neapolis: at first in two words, Νέα πόλις, gen. Νέης πόλιος Hdt. 2.91, cf. Th. 7.50; later in one, Νεάπολις, gen. Νεαπόλεως Str. 2.5.40, dat. Νεαπόλει Id. 1.2.13: hence Νεοπολίτης [ῑ], ου, ὁ, IG 1(2).191.31, al., later Νεαπολίτης Tab.Heracl. 1.187, Lyc. 736, Plb. 1.20.14, etc., cf. Pl. ap. Poll. 9.26.
sounding new, διάλεξις Philostr. VS 2.8.2.
praesalsus, prob. in Gloss.
make new, refresh, Plu. QConv. 2.702c:—in Med., freshen up, τὴν τῆς ὕλης σύστασιν Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.44.

children.label: II
children.definition: freshen the edges of an ulcer by removing granulations, ν. ἕλκος, κοιλώματα, Antyll. ap. Orib. 44.23.4, Ruf. ap.eund.8.24.48.
renew, repeat, Sor. 2.41 ( Pass.), Aët. 15.2 ( Act.).
possessing youthful charm, metaph., of style, Aristid. Rh. 2p.551S.; becoming or natural in youth, Procl. in Alc. pp. 23,47C.; τὸ ν. τῶν ἠθῶν Id. in Cra. p.1 P., cf. Olymp. in Phlb. p.249S.

definition: νεαρός, ά, όν, poet. for νέος (also in later Prose, v. infr.),

children.definition: youthful, παῖδες Il. 2.289, cf. Pi. P. 10.25, etc.; τὸ ἦθος νεαρός, opp. νέος τὴν ἡλικίαν, Arist. EN 1095a7; νεαροί youths, A. Ag. 359, 1504 (both anap.); ν. ἥβη Ar. Fr. 467; = νεαλής, ν. στρατός Hdn. 3.7.5; τὸ ν. youthful spirit, X. Cyr. 1.4.3; λόγος ν. καὶ θεατρικός Plu. Praec. 2.802e; σχηματισμοὶ πολὺ τὸ ν. ἔχοντες D.H. Comp. 23.

new, ὕμνοι Hes. Fr. 265; νεαρὰ ἐξευρεῖν Pi. N. 8.20; fresh, μυελός A. Ag. 76 (anap.); σώματα X. Cyn. 9.10; ν. δέλεαρ, opp. σαπρόν, Arist. HA 534b4; τροφή Id. PA 675b29; ν. τυρός, ὄστρεα, Dsc. 2.71, Ath. 1.7d; -ώτεροι κλῶνες Gal. 12.283; καππάρεως ὅτι -ωτάτης PCair.Zen. 488 (iii B.C.).
recent, ξυντυχίαι S. Ant. 157 (anap.); of a letter, D.L. 1.112.
αἱ νεαραί (sc. διατάξεις) title of the novellae of Justinian; ἡ θεία καὶ ν. διάταξις PGrenf. 1.62.13 (vi A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. -ρῶς youthfully, rawly, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 50: Comp., διειλεγμένον -ωτέρως with more spirit, Isoc. 12.229. [ νεα- by synizesis, as one long syll., Pi. ll.cc.; cf. νηρός.]
newly-bearing, Gloss.
IG 7.1773 (Thesp.).
rejuvenation, Poet. in PIand. 78.13.

definition: νέας, Ion. acc. pl. from ναῦς.

children.definition: novella, Gloss.
to be ploughed up, of fallow land, Gloss.
breaking-up of fallow land, ν. θερινή Thphr. CP 3.20.7 ( νέανσις codd.).
newly-soled, Stratt. 47.8.

definition: νεάτη [ᾰ] (sc. χορδή), ἡ, Dor. νεάτα Philol. 6:—

children.definition: the lowest of the three strings which formed the framework of the musical scale (opp. μέση, ὑπάτη), but the highest in pitch, Cratin. 134, Pl. R. 443d:— contr. νήτη Arist. Ph. 224b34, Metaph. 1018b28, 1057a23, Alex.Eph. ap.Theon.Sm. p.140 H., etc.: in pl., ἐπὶ τὰς νήτας . . ἀναβαίνειν, in declamation, Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.10.23. (Orig. fem. of νέατος (A).)

definition: νέατος (A), Ep. νείᾰτος, η, ον, poet. Sup.,

children.definition: uttermost, lowest, Hom. (who uses the νει- form exc. in Il. 11.712, 9.153, 295), always of Space, the lowest part of . . , ν. ἀνθερεών, κενεών, ὦμος, Il. 5.293, 857, 15.341; extreme, outermost, ὄρχος Od. 7.127; ἀστράγαλος Il. 14.466; ν. πείρατα γαίης 8.478; ὑπαὶ πόδα ν. Ἴδης the lowest slope of Ida, 2.824; ἐκ ν. πυθμένος εἰς κορυφήν Sol. 13.10; πόδες ν. the feet, Orac. ap. Hdt. 7.140; νείατον ἰνίον A.R. 3.763, cf. 2.166: c. gen., ν. ἄλλων Il. 6.295; πόλις νεάτη Πύλου on the border of Pylos, 11.712; πᾶσαι δʼ ἐγγὺς ἁλὸς νέαται Πύλου ἠμαθόεντος 9.153, 295 (wrongly expld. ap.Sch. as 3 pl. pres. ind. (like κέαται) of ναίω, to be situated):— rare in Prose, τὰς νεάτας πλευράς Hp. Int. 27, and cf. νεάτη; contr. νῆτος· ἔσχατος, Hsch.; Arc. νήατος Schwyzer 664.10 (Orchom. Arc., iv B.C.). (The orig. form may be νήατος; with νείατος, νέατος, cf. εἵαται, ἕαται (v. ἧμαι), εἵως, ἕως, etc.; cf. νήϊστος, νείαιρα, νειόθεν, νειόθι.)

data.quote: πᾶσαι δʼ ἐγγὺς ἁλὸς νέαται Πύλου ἠμαθόεντος

definition: νέατος (B), η, ον, poet. (post- Hom.) Sup. of νέος,

children.definition: latest, last, ν. γέννημα S. Ant. 627 (anap.); τὰν ν. ὁδὸν στείχουσαν, ν. δὲ φέγγος λεύσσουσαν ib. 807 (lyr.); τίς ἄρα νέατος . . λήξει; i.e. ὥστε νέατος γενέσθαι, Id. Aj. 1185 (lyr.): neut. νέατον as Adv., for the last time, E. Tr. 201 (lyr.).
breaking-up of fallow land, X. Oec. 7.20.

plough up, of fallow land, ἢν νεᾶν βούλησθε . . τοὺς ἀγρούς Ar. Nu. 1117: metaph., τὰν μέσαν νεῶν ἄρουραν (in music) Pratin.Lyr. 5: abs., Eup. 13, Thphr. CP 3.20.7: aor. 1 subj. νεάσωσι ib. 3.20.8:— Pass., νεωμένη (sc. γῆ) land ploughed up, after lying fallow, Hes. Op. 462.

definition: νεβλάραι (fort. νεβλᾶραι) · περαίνειν, Hsch.; νεβλάρεται Ar. Fr. 241 (ap. Phot., -τοι cod.).
νέβλεστα <τὰ> περιτάλματα τῶν ἱερῶν ( Sicel), Hsch.

children.definition: cockerel, Hsch.
of a fawn, ὀστέα, αὐλοί, Call. Dian. 244, APl. 16.305 (Antip.).

definition: νεβρῆ, contr. for νεβρέη (sc. δορά), ἡ,

children.definition: fawnskin, Orph. Fr. 238.8; ν. παρδαλέη Id. A. 449.
dappled like a fawn, γαλεός Arist. HA 565a26, cf. Hsch. s.v. λάδας.

definition: νεβρίδιον [ῐδ], τό, Dim. of νεβρίς, Artem. 4.72.

children.definition: clad in fawnskin, of Dionysus and the Bacchae, AP 9.524.14.
wear a fawnskin at the feast of Dionysus, or, as trans., robe in fawnskins ( Phot. gives both explanations), D. 18.259.
of a fawn, δορά S. Ichn. 219.

definition: νεβρίς, ἡ, gen. ίδος [ῐ] E. Ba. 136 (lyr.; late ῖδος D.P. 703, 946), νεβρίδα E. Ba. 24, Thesp. 1, νεβρίσι E. Ba. 249, νεβρίδας ib. 696:—

children.definition: fawnskin, esp. as the dress of Dionysus and the Bacchae, Il.cc.
wearing of a νεβρίς, Arignote ap. Harp.
like a fawnskin, ν. λίθος, a precious stone, Orph. L. 748:—also νεβρ-ῖτις, ιδος, ἡ, Plin. HN 37.175.
of a fawnʼs leg, i.e. a flute, Cleobulina 3 (dub.l.).
to be changed into a fawn, Nonn. D. 10.60.

young of the deer, fawn, Il. 8.248, Od. 4.336, etc.; πέδιλα νεβρῶν fawnskin brogues, Hdt. 7.75; a type of cowardice, Il. 4.243, 21.29; prov., ὁ ν. τὸν λέοντα (sc. αἱρεῖ), of anything strange, Luc. DMort. 18[8].1:—also fem., Il. 4.243, E. Ba. 866 (lyr.), Trag.Adesp. 419.
bringing forth fawns, Nic. Th. 142.
fawn-like, Nonn. D. 5.363.
preying on fawns, ν. [ἀετός], = πύγαργος, Arist. HA 618b20.
clad in a νεβρίς, Simm. 15.
fawn-like, of Dionysus, AP 9.524.14.

definition: νεδίας τὰς αἰθυίας, Hsch. νέες, νέεσσι, v. ναῦς.

children.definition: new-born, just born, Od. 4.336.
fresh-blown, young, E. Ion 112 (lyr.).

definition: νεήκης (on the accent v. Hdn.Gr. 1.82), Dor. νεάκης Hsch. ( -κίς cod.), ες: ( ἀκή A):—

children.definition: newly whetted or sharpened, Il. 13.391.

definition: νεηκονής, ές, ( ἀκόνη) = foreg., S. Aj. 820.
νεηλαίη, ἡ, Ion. for νεολαία, Hsch. ( νέηλαι cod.).

children.definition: rower, Hsch.
newly-forged, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἐλατήρ III, ἔλατρον) freshly rolled out: νεήλατα, τά, new cakes, D. 18.260 (expld. by Harp. fr. ἀλέω A).
fresh-plastered, οἰκίαι Arist. Pr. 899b18.
newcomer, Il. 10.434, Hdt. 1.118, Pl. Lg. 879d.
newly milked, Nic. Al. 311.

definition: νεηνίης, νεῆνις, νεηνίσκος, Ion. for νεᾱν-: so νέηξ for νέαξ.

children.definition: cut or castrated when young, AP 6.234 ( Eryc.).
newly revealed, ὄσσα h.Merc. 443.

definition: νεί, Boeot. for νή, Ar. Ach. 867, 905; also Arc., IG 5(2).343.42 (Orchom.).
νείαιρα, acc. sg. -ᾰν Il. 16.465, Hp. Mul. 1.64, 2.137, Nat.Mul. 5, 6, al. (codd. opt.), Call. Fr. 106 codd., Nic. Al. 270; dat. -ῃ Il. (v. infr.):—

children.definition: Adj. (formed like γέραιρα) with comp. sense, lower, νειαίρῃ δʼ ἐν γαστρί in the lower part of the belly, Il. 5.539, 616, cf. Hp. ll.cc.; νείαιραν σάρκα Nic. l.c.:—also νέαιρα, νέαιραν γνάθον Simon. 244.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., ἡ νείαιρα the abdomen, βάρος ἐν νειαίρῃ Hp. Coac. 579, cf. Call. l.c.; cf. νειρός (A). (Cogn. with νέατος (A): orig. perh. *νήαιρα, whence νέαιρα (lengthd. to νείαιρα in text of Hom.), contr. *νῇρα, whence νεῖρα.)

definition: νειάτιος [ᾰ], η, ον, later form for νείατος, νέατος (A), Man. 6.738.

children.definition: wrangler: c. gen., one who wrangles with, ἐσθλῶν ν. Hes. Op. 716.

definition: νεικέω, fut. -έσω Il. 10.115: aor. ἐνείκεσα, Ep. νείκεσσα or νείκεσα, 3.38, 10.158: also pres. νεικείω 2.277, etc.; subj. νεικείῃσι, νεικείῃ, 1.579, Hes. Op. 332; part. νεικείουσα Theoc. 1.35: impf. νείκειον Od. 22.26; iterat. νεικείεσκον Il. 4.241: ( νεῖκος):—

children.definition: quarrel, wrangle with one, μή μοι ὀπίσσω νεικείῃ Od. 17.189; ἔριδος πέρι θυμοβόροιο νεικεῦσʼ ἀλλήλῃσι quarrel one with another, Il. 20.254; ἐνείκεον εἵνεκα ποινῆς 18.498: c. acc. cogn., νείκεα . . νεικεῖν ἀλλήλοισιν ἐναντίον 20.252; νεικέσκομεν οἴω, we two alone strove with him, is prob. corrupt in Od. 11.512 ( νικάσκομεν Aristarch.): abs. in part. νεικέων Hdt. 9.55.

children.label: II
children.definition: chide, rail at, upbraid, c. acc. pers., Il. 1.521, al.; Ἀγαμέμνονα ν. μύθῳ 2.224; αἰσχροῖς, ὀνειδείοις, χολωτοῖσιν ἐπέεσσιν, 3.38, 21.480, Od. 22.225, etc.; ὃς νείκεσσε θεάς . . , τὴν δʼ ᾔνησʼ [Paris] insulted the goddesses (Hera and Athena), but praised the other ( Aphrodite), Il. 24.29.— Ep. Verb, used twice by Hdt., 8.125, 9.55; not in Att.: in later Prose, LXX Pr. 10.12, al.
